My understanding is that health costs in the vast majority of countries are increasing at well above inflation costs, so nothing really Swiss here, except the way the costs are passed on. 
In countries with government run health systems, such as France or the UK, the increased costs are broadly just tagged on to government debt and left to later generations to deal with. Not everyone likes to receice gifts in general, or happens to like the particular gift. In this case the recipients are 2 or 3 people, depending how you count, and they may not share the same opinion about the gift itself.   
I offer this in some sort if defence, from memories of having agonised over how to possibly fulfil the dreaded instruction to write a thank-you note for something that I personally wished I had not been made to receive in the first place.   
For my own sake, if ever I give a gift, I consider it as having left my possession and having tranferred over to the other person, who is then free to do what they want with it, including giving it away or selling it. In my way of feeling (when a giver), a recipient who takes the trouble to write thank-you note is doing a good, upstanding, nice, respectable thing, but I try not to hang about expecting it, and try to set the recipient free from any such duty - most especially if they are parents of a newborn baby. I don't always succeed in being so noble, though.   
Perhaps a thank-you note is more mportant when the giver(s) acted out of a  selfless generosity that does not stem from any personal connection, just strangers who were hugely compassionate and generous.     
I know of such a case currently, where many good folk pooled together, contributing smaller and larger sums, even spreading the news of the need amongst friends even further removed, and only thanks to this amazing support by so many could the little boat (metaphorically speaking) be successful rescued from the storms and brought into safety.... and not one thank-you note in there, from the captain of the little boat, not even after a break to rest. 
I found it very sad.

Castro - This is a bit different than your problem, but we have a Samsung refrigerator/freezer that does not have an icemaker. The problem we have is the freezer (at the bottom) had a defrost problem that was causing the cooling cycle (of fridge and freezer) to turn itself off quite often, resulting in a worse problem.    
I defrosted it myself a few times, using a hair dryer for about an hour. But it kept coming back. Eventually, I found that the ice had built up way back in the cooling system and I needed to let it thaw overnight for all of the ice to melt. Now that all of the "cooling passages" are unblocked, everything seems to work correctly again. The unit is at least 7 yrs old, so pretty happy with its durability now that I understand what the problem is/was.   
Good luck with the new fridge!

The answer is no. Easy. As much as I'd like to believe otherwise, I doubt it'll be the first white lie you've ever told in an interview.    
As to the getting upset part (i.e. red face) - why? People are people all over, over, but that doesn't mean the interview norms are the same as "back home". Maybe he's making conversation in a thoughtless way, maybe he's trying to decide whether or not to hire you... but either way, getting upset doesn't help. Take a deep breath and let it slide.   
Have a look at Phil's point. If you hire someone who goes on maternity leave half a year later, you've spent a lot of money to poor effect (and will have to spend more to hire and train a temp while that person is out). It sucks from their point of view, just as it sucks from your point of view to be discriminated against.   
I say this not to justify, but to help you empathize - they're running a business and have to think about the costs. Realize that, understand it, and use that understanding to keep yourself calm next time it happens - it'll work out better for you in the long run.

You say you pay Fr. 300 per month to rent that parking space.  In that case, the fact that an unauthorised car is preventing you from using what you're paying for might constitute a shortcoming (Mangel) of the rented object.     
If this is the case - and I'd suggest you ask the Mieterverband whether this reasoning is sound - then it would be the duty of your landlord to have the offending car removed, so that you, once again, can used the space to which you are entitled.     
If the landlord does not do so, after you have requested in in writing, and set a date by which the shortcoming must be fixed, then you could threaten to pay your rent into a blocked account until they do.   
Next port of call, I'd say, is the Mieterverband.

This article in the Beobachter  
explains that the police are not the correct adddress for cars parked on private grounds.  It goes on to warn that the costs of having the car towed, if for any reason not paid by the car's owner, can be charged to the person who called out the tow-service (you).  However, the article concludes with the remark that  
"Diese [die Vermieterschaft] ist dafür verantwortlich, dass Sie Ihr Mietobjekt vertragsgemäss nützen können." 
The landlord is responsible for ensuring that you can use the object you have rented according the the conditions of the contract.

I understand that the little ants with which you house would appear to be infested are well known for such nocturnal nibblings, which accounts for their name in German: Schafseckelameisen. In days gone by, farmers would be forced to protect their rams by all kinds of arcane means, for once an army of ants had acquired a taste for scrotal scran, it was almost impossible to get rid of them. They would nestle between the little woolly hairs down there, munching away quite merrily, while the ram was rapidly driven to insanity, thus becoming utterly useless to the farmer, except as a source of wool or as a rather inefficient beast of burden (there is a wide selection of ram saddles and yokes in the permanent exhibition of the Sheep Museum in Wollerau, should you happen to be Welsh).   
Obviously, as a human, a good scratch is clearly a very satisfactory option, should your nether regions become infested by such formidable formicid fiends, so insanity is unlikely to result from such an itchy invasion.   
Precautions are advisable, all the same, however. There's only so much distraction a gentleman can take while enjoying a good book, a cup of hot chocolate, a game of Twister, or whatever else he might choose to do in the comfort of his bed chamber.   
You may want to lay off the cigars, though, at least until the ants have gone.

Okay, before I go into this, I should note that the comment above on the sudden shift in currency is really important in all this. by having the prices articifically spiked by twenty or more percent, it has really upset the apple cart on a lot of this. That said, as someone in manufacturing here, my $0.02 is:   
If the Swiss want to claim that their high cost of labor is offset by their high productivity, then it has to show up in their prices in the form of being competitive. It's really as simple as that. If something costs more in Switzerland than the higher cost has simply resulted in...higher cost. If the price isn't competitive, it is silly to ask a consumer to spend their money poorly. I see no reason to pay more for something because it is Swiss. If it happens to also be better, then yes.    
As a manufacturer, I   tell my customers to buy my stuff instead of the Germans' because we are Swiss. Either we get our cost out if we are competiting head-to-head, or we find a way to give the customer a unique value. But it is never sensible to ask a customer to pay more if you are not providing more for the money in some form. And, if you are going to rely on that strategy, there will be a reckoning for you one day, and, in turn, your employees, and their pension funds. Maybe it's when someone like Aldi crashes your market, or when the local economy shrinks and you can't diversify outside of your country because you are not competitive, or when your cusotmers simply stop buying from you because it no longers makes sense for them. But one day, it will come.   
But I would never support telling the consumer base that they should overspend to help support a little price fantasyland. It does the consumer no favors, and, in the long term, it does the seller no favors, either.

Just a quick note on the way things might more normally have gone.   
1. Post(s) reported by member(s) - lots of posts from a new member not really saying anything often means they're only here to flog something. We probably get 10-20 such reports every day. 
2. Mod takes a look, maybe once or twice per day sees a lot that are typical of this sort of thing, and deletes them with a short explanation. 
3. Occasionally, a genuine new member PMs the mod with a question about why they were deleted, explaining that they're not spammers at all, and were just trying to be helpful, friendly or both. 
4. Posts are reinstated with an apology and an explanation as to why we take such action. 
5. New member goes away happy, with a little more understanding of the way things are, all posts and reputation intact.  
6. Nobody else is involved in or even aware of the process; the original post reporter assumes we've looked into it and dealt with it appropriately.   
It's a thankless task, I tells ya

post:
IIRC BMW services are: 
Oil 
Service 1 
Oil 
Service 2 
(Repeat)   
They are based on driving and for your average person will be every 25,000km (or 2 years).   
An Oil service will include the oil being drained (not vacuumed), the sump plug replaced with a fresh washer, oil filter replaced and fresh oil added. That oil will be a high quality full synthetic oil. They will also replace the filters as per the schedule and also any other parts as per the schedule.   
On top of that they'll also give the car a good check underneath - looking for any wear on the joints, bushes etc etc.   
^^That can not be compared to a "cheap" oil change in the US/UK - where the oil is vacuumed out (dragging the particles from the sump back through the engine) and fresh mineral oil is added. That is OK for a OHV engine with low compression and 5,000km oil change intervals - but not for a modern car.

There is the other option, which is focussed on monthly cost. Going back to our 50k car (again at 5.4%, 4 years, 30% residual and can do 7l/100km over 15k km per year) 
LEASE: 653chf + 166chf (savings) + 158chf (fuel) = 977chf per month    
If our monthly budget is 977chf to "hire/buy + fuel" a car, and assuming that the car will be older (less efficent 8l/100km) the numbers come out as: 
PURCHASE: 797chf (savings) + 180chf fuel = 977chf per month. This gives a budget of 38,400chf for the car.   
For someone who will change cars in line with the length of the lease and "uses" the car rather than considering it an asset, leasing can allow them to drive a newer or better or more efficient car.   
The car market in Switzerland is relatively illiquid and this means that transfering this risk can really be worthwhile

No need to react at all. In fact, you can open the package and use it, gift it forward, or throw it away (selling the contents forward may be a bad idea, not sure). An exception to this: If you may have received it due to an honest mistake, e.g. if you're John Doe and the package is addressed to Johnny Doe.   
However, since we're on an eglish speaking forum, you may have inadvertantly accepted to be sent the package on the phone, and thus sealed a contract. Unless you're sure you didn't it might be a good idea do send them a letter ("Eingeschrieben", Registered Mail, keep the receipt) and ask why they're sending you this, and tell them to provide any proof they may have that actually a contract has been agreed upon (note: recording a phone call is illegal unless you've been told that it will be recorded).   
From the relevant law, Obligationenrecht §6a 
Art. 6a2 
1 Die Zusendung einer unbestellten Sache ist kein Antrag. 
2 Der Empfänger ist nicht verpflichtet, die Sache zurückzusenden oder 
aufzubewahren. 
3 Ist eine unbestellte Sache offensichtlich irrtümlich zugesandt worden, 
so muss der Empfänger den Absender benachrichtigen.    
Art. 6a2 
1 The sending of goods does not constitute an application [meaning this isn't grounds for a contract, the counterpart to an offer by the seller] 
2 The recipient is not obliged to return said goods, or to store them. 
3 If the unordered goods have been sent due to an obvious(apparent?) mistake, then the recipient has to inform the sender.

As a Publican here in the CH... here's some help.     
Firstly, most Kantons have strong drinking and licence laws! Most have a curfew of Midnight thirty for outsiders with drinks in hand and on the table (which means you can't do much about smokers yabbering late at night, but they're NOT allowed drinks outside after 00.30!)     
Just up till two o-clock (?) sounds strange to me. Late licences (after 00.30) continue on till 4.00am. Check with the local council if the Bar/Restaurant has a late licence. If not, phone police after the drinking up time. They'll get the picture very quick, as each violation becomes more and more expensive with the loss of licences in the end.     
Bars have to pay an expensive premium to stay open longer, so if someone is selling 'after time' it's not fair on the ones who pay and stay legal. Do the sods!     
To sum up... check with the council about the drinking up and no drinks outside times, and then check about his late licence, or lack of.     
If they're breaking the rules, it wont take very long to put a stop to them.     
Good Luck     
GREG

Well, I have read quite of few of these threads relating to police searches, unfair assumptions, etc. and I think there are a few things that come to mind when I read the responses.  I have only been on the forum for two months so I realize that I don't have the perspective of those who have been active here for years.  This response is more about the topic of authority in general than a specific response to this particular search. 
     It seems that quite a few people are not interested in debating these issues, but rather want to end the possibility of a balanced discussion as quickly as possible.  Perhaps this is because it has been discussed so many times, perhaps people feel strongly that authorities should be able to use their powers how they see fit.  I find the topic pretty fascinating and don't see exactly why people seem so sensitive about this as a discussion.  To me, a free society or a free forum should not shy away from such discussions and it is definitely possible for authority figures to behave improperly--even in the most civilized, ordered societies.  I mean, I am an American, and have seen authority misused in my country time and time again from authorities ranging from law enforcement, teachers, government officials, etc.  I fully realize that these same authority figures have also saved many lives, locked up dangerous people, and helped many people .  But, I know that if their mistakes are not brought up and exposed to society, they are unlikely to improve and more likely to abuse their powers.   
   From what the original poster wrote, it is difficult to know exactly how the encounter with the police went down.  But, I think most police are good at asking questions and figuring out who is lying--so I think that is the first step they should take in such an encounter.  I think searching may be within their rights, but shouldn't be used unless they still believe it to be necessary after questioning exposes doubts in their mind.  If the police believe they or the public are in immediate danger, than they can act more forcefully or quickly.

post: Did you pay by credit card? Just inform your card issuer that you have not received the goods and ask them to cancel the (financial) transaction.  Technically, it's called "disputing a charge". Don't pay the invoiced amount when you receive your credit card statement. If you have paid already, still dispute the charge -- you will ultimately be refunded.

You can still call up your former bank and ask to issue your statements from any of the last 5 years. I should cost you about 35.- to 50.- (depending on a bank) and you'll have the printouts in your hands about a week later.       Yes, unfortunately it can. This year tax authorities sent a letter to a friend of mine, saying that they've noticed he hasn't paid his tax in full in 2010... Needless to say, he had to pay the outstanding amount.        Don't take it personally. Very often it's the electronic claims system that words things this way, so there isn't a 'human touch' in there at all. I once had an accident and received a letter from my employer referring to it as a "claim no 123" and what should be done. There was no word of "we are sorry you suffered a major injury and would like to help you." I had a chuckle!       Here's where asking nicely might play in your favor. Don't write any emotional letters back. Instead go and have a chat with the front desk staff or a manager, if possible, and try to sort things out nicely. It might be that their acc dept made a mistake, so it's def worth asking!    
Best of luck!!!

Ducko, I'm so very sorry to hear about your dog.    
While the trainer was within her rights if she listed a cancellation policy in your contract, or if she had posted her cancellation policy in her AGBs and you had checked a box saying that you agreed to those...   
... can I just say that I am shocked.    
My trainer, too, has cancellation a policy - as do the sports club, my dogsitter, and my various vet practices - any dog-related service I use.    
And none would ever even   of charging me if I cancelled an appointment in such circumstances.    
(And yes, I've had to cancel appointments for health care emergencies many times, and even cancelled whole contracts when members of the Muttley Crew died.)   
Boggles the mind - Surely a bit of humanity is called for at such a sad - and clearly exceptional - time. Moreover, treating a bereaved customer this way would make me think that this trainer is not the kind of person I would want around my dog.    
I hope that, when your heart has had time to heal, another four-footed friend one day finds his/her way to you. And when that happens - find another trainer.  I can assure you - what you experienced is not what I would expect from a fellow dog lover.   
Again, I am sorry for your loss.     
ETA:   
RE: The financial side:   
Dog training is about building a relationship with the owner - it's a business dependent on repeat customers.  The death of a dog - the whole reason the business relationship exists - is not the same as a 'simple' missed appointment. All the dog service providers I use understand this - which is the reason I'm happy to spend most of my disposable income, year after year after year, with them. IMO, the OP's trainer was being 'penny wise and pound foolish' in this case...

- 17 Fr. administrative fee 
- 8 Fr. Vorlagenprovision (interest for their generousity to advance the VAT to the customs)       
Their advise for frequent importers is to open a ZAZ-Konto ("Zentralisiertes Abrechnungsverfahren der Zollverwaltung"), DHL won't charge you this 25 Fr. if you have one.   
There is nothing for you to get back because web shops from the US don't include VAT in their prices.

In all the places I've lived when growing up, while this was not exclusive to certain types of communities, it certainly was more prevalent...  The type of community was one where generations of families tended to be born and die in the same town or cluster of towns.    
Hardly anybody new moves there, and hardly anybody leaves, so they have not needed to develop the type of social skill necessary to be welcoming of newcomers - after all, they've known all their friends at least since kindergarten.   
All is not lost though, these folks tend to be very friendly once they get to know you, and very inclusive, but it takes a while (sometimes a looooong while).   
Think back to the party, or ask your hubby, if there are any particular who he'd be more likely to socialize with in smaller groups. Invite them around to yours (maybe in pairs or so), so that you have a chance at conversation and getting to know them in a setting where YOU are the one who is most comfortable and at ease. This will help you and them at the same time, giving you a chance to shine and be yourself.   
On the bright side, at least it seems your Swiss hubby is social, mine is not, so I've had to find friends where I may (not a bad thing, but not easy either).   
Good luck, and best wishes for the three of you, including of course your little one.

The process is not only complicated, but also expensive. Think of it dispassionately - why should a company jump through hoops for a non-EU candidate when there are several equally qualified EU candidates also applying? This is the crux of the issue - unless there are no CH/EU candidates, it makes little economic sense for a company to pursue a non-EU permit. It isn't discrimination, it's economics.      Again, you need to understand the market. There are plenty of quants looking for work who have those skills plus years of experience - and some of those don't need work permits either. Again, not discrimination, but rather market conditions.   
It's a tough time for non-EU folks in Switzerland - one needs to understand this, and deal with the market as it is.  It seems like every month for the last year or so I've been saying good-bye to yet another friend who has had to leave Switzerland, as jobs in the field you are looking to enter are cut.    
Your best bet is to concentrate on what it is that makes you an outstanding candidate - what do you have that no one else can offer? This is what you need to motivate a company to go to bat for you.

They both do so. COOP started the PrixGarantie products-line while Migros started the Budget prodocts-line. Also to have alcohol and tobacco on offer, Migros first allied with and later bought Denner, which is on the same price-level as Aldi and Lidl. To counter Migrol, COOP started COOP petrol stations. To counter this, Migros bought the ARAL -CH petrol stations and the ARAL shops.  The ARAL shops were turned into   but still sell tobacco, beer and wine. To get a heavier say in regard to   they recently, in conjunction with SOCAR, purchased the former ESSO shops who continue to sell tobacco and alcohol. To outdistance COOP in regard to Germany and to improve its purchasing power, Migros-Zürich purchased TEGUT in Germany. The   of COOP according to rumours is full.  But in the past few years, COOP purchased InterDiscount, Fust.  It will be interesting to see the next move of COOP.   
Back to Migros. The present plans of the Migros group see a big expansion of Denner, but not much expansion of the mainline shops   
On the side of COOP, it was amazing to see how Hansueli Loosli between 1997 and 2011 (14 years) heavily transformed COOP into a modern enterprise   
At Migros, Mr Bolliger will step down in 2017.  He in his time gradually DEcentralized Migros and gave the various M-cooperatives much more independence, which gives more flexibility to the group. Quite along the ideas of Gottblieb Duttweiler.  COOP at the other hand grew out of the cooperatives-section of the SocialDemocratic Party and so has a different legacy. In order to break the influence of party-people, Loosli rather centralized the whole structure. The challenge to his successor(s) is not an easy one.

"Die Post" is actually doing something strange with their shipping costs. 
A very light enveloppe (I believe up to 250 grams) may be up to 5 cm think. 
A heavier enveloppe may only be 2 cm thick. In other words: a thin enveloppe may be up to 1kg, whereas a thick enveloppe may only be 250 grams... 
If you drop off an enveloppe in the yellow mailbox, it may be that it was too thick and/or too heavy and then it is suddenly treated as a package (which will suddenly cost a lot more).

As someone who was involved in forming the Star Alliance and flies far too much, I will tell you this:   
1) Some of this depends upon airline.  Swiss and Lufthansa have slightly different internal electronic procedures than United and Air Canada.   
2)  Make _sure_ that your frequent flier status is properly in your seat allocation, as some of these will prevent you from being in the unhappy box of "ticket booked, seat unallocated".  I have been in that box, and it is not a good box to be in.  But it usually occurs on an airline where either: (a) I have no frequent flier account, or (b) low status on the airline.   
3)  My recent experience with Swiss was a case in point.  I am a 1K with United (Gold Star Alliance), and the travel agent put in the wrong frequent flier number for me, which meant: (a) I nearly didn't get a seat; and (b) the seat I was given was next to the toilet in the last row on the 12 hour flight to Miami.  I emailed Swiss in advance of my return to Switzerland from LA, explained what had happened, they corrected the information in the system and within 24 hours -- but 10 days before my flight back -- they issued me an economy seat that was in a respectable part of the plane.  And apologized for the seating error previously.      
I suppose I wouldn't have minded being in the last row of the plane, but: (a) I had a business meeting scheduled and needed to exit the plane as fast as possible; and (b) I was surrounded by about 40 drunk Swedes heading on a group holiday to Miami.

A)  if you, in the times when the USA still had the draft, did military service in Switzerland, you were NOT to be taken into the military once back in the USA. This was the reason why in the late 60ies and early 70ies, uncountable dual citizens who lived in the USA came over to Switzerland and did military service, in order to keep out of the War in Vietnam (I was the defacto translator of such a chap in the "RS", and learnt a lot of English that way) 
B)  if you as a dual citizen lived in the USA for more than 10 years, you could visit Switzerland without the risk to be charged with military taxes. THIS was checked up by my uncle and his wife (based in Marshall/TX) in 1958, He had lived in TX+LA since 1905 .  Things between 1955 and early 58 were checked up with the CH-embassy in W-DC and the military command of the Canton of Schaffhausen. As the NON-CH wife of him did most of the work, it was Mum who did the translating for the office in Schaffhausen.   
BUT then two major questions : 
> How old were you when coming over to Switzerland ?   If less than 20 years old you are considered a CH citizen who has to do military service ! 
>  Have you done service in any part of USA armed forces ?  If not, then you have to accept to be up for military service here

I spend lots and lots of time playing basketball here in Switzerland. Thats not normal for some one my age. But since I hang out at the parks here a couple of evenings a week I do get a chance to meet these "problem teens" all the time and have made friends with most of them.    
In my experience they are almost all the children of foreigners. In my area all yugoslavians, Algerians and a couple of Polish kids. They are not bad kids. In particular the Algerian kids take care of their brothers and sisters very well.    
But you cant expect a child to raise its self.    
In all of the years I have lived here and known all of these kids not once have I met any of their parents. From talking to the kids their parents all work one or two jobs in order to have 2 cars and an apartment. They spend almost zero time with their kids. Do you know who talks to these kids about smoking? Me.... Im not their fuking mom. Yet Im the only one who has ever addressed that issue with them. These kids are 15 years old.    
I made one Albanian kid (Who I know his father very very well) return stolen porn mags from the local BP. These kids arent criminals, they are just bored out of their minds. I personally think these kids dont get the love they need. Mom and dad dont get home until 9pm most nights.    
But thats just my experience. Many of these kids dont drink or smoke or do drugs. They just get bored and want to show off for friends. They have no life inside their house. The job of parent is the most important in the world. You cant expect anyone or anything to raise your kids for you.

One of my more surreal customer service experiences here:   
Saw something I liked in a baby clothing store in Zürich, asked the assistant if she had it in size 12 months.   
Sales assistant: "Oh yes, we have that size."    
Me: "Wonderful. I'll take it. Would you gift wrap it please?"   
Sales assistant: "Oh no, I can't sell this one to you. I can't have one size missing from the display."   
Me: "Do you have another in stock?"   
Sales assistant: "Yes, but I can't bring it out if there is one on the floor."   
Me: "But if you sell me this one, there would no longer be one on the floor and you could bring another out of the stockroom..."   
Sales assistant: "But I can't I sell this one to you. I can't have one size missing from the display..."   
Me:

I have noticed a similar incident happening to one of my friends. This guy had just landed in Zurich airport and we took him to the SBB counter to buy a "monthly" Zurich Zone 10 ticket. Before him, another friend of mine renewed his monthly and then we bought his. 
But we did not notice that he was issue the ticket on the customer ID of my friend (the counter guy forgot to change the ID). 
After couple of weeks we were checked in the S-Bahn and this guy was caught because "he was travelling on someone else's ticket" and was fined (No fault on part of the ticket inspector though) 
He was issued an invoice to pay. 
Next day we took that invoice to the Airport counter and explained the matter to the same guy who issued the ticket. 
He understood his mistake and cancelled the fine then and there. 
We were lucky that he was brave enough to admit that it was his fault and we didn't have to go through the process of calling/writing to the SBB.   
But, this things happens and you have to accept uit. But at the same time do all the calling and writing to resolve the issue. Its not about some CHFs, but its about the principal.   
I wish you all the best and yes, you should also claim for all the cost you have incurred to resolve this.

I guess I'm old, too. I *always* wear earplugs at gigs, no matter how loud or soft they are or where I am in the room.    
Normally I'm up front taking photos (which often means a head in a speaker...and that's usually during extreme metal gigs), but even if I'm in the back I wear my plugs.    
Back when I was 18 or 19, Motorhead played a gig at an old theater in the town where I grew up - it ended up being in the Guinness book of world records as the unofficial loudest concert ever. The ceiling started to crumble and plaster was on everyone's shoulders. I stayed in the lobby of the theater, maybe lasted five or six songs and left - I could still hear it clear as day inside my car with the windows rolled up blocks away. I was deaf for a few days afterwards, all I could hear was ringing. I remember going to lectures at university and not hearing a thing.    
My dad, who worked at an auto factory, brought me home earplugs after that, and I've worn them religiously ever since. I still have hearing trouble and can't make out what people say when there's loud backgruond noise.    
Personally, I'm always grateful when the security guys have extra earplugs to hand out when I'm up front.

I'm English, but I was brought up not to flush the toilet at night unless it was... necessary... to avoid disturbing the rest of the house.   
I would suggest that if you can leave it until morning, do so.    
On the other hand, there are times when you need to flush. And I'm sure that most people appreciate this. When I've had a stomach bug, for example, and have been flushing the toilet frequently in the night, no-one's ever complained. Or sometimes I just forget, if I'm feeling drowsy, and I flush without thinking.    
So perhaps your neighbour is getting frustrated that you seem (from her point of view) to be flushing the toilet at night on a regular basis in disregard of the conventions here.    
I suggest a positive approach would be to write a polite note to all your neighbours (i.e. not signalling this particular lady out) explaining that you work shifts, and that you may therefore disturb them when you have to leave early / come home late, and that you hope they understand that any noises you may make are not due to a lack of consideration but due to your work circumstances, and that you will try and keep such noises to a minimum. Just to put a couple of things in context for you to hopefully make you feel a bit less frustrated:   
Firstly, The 10 stop filter or Big Stoppers are in huge demand & the production of them is having trouble keeping up, this was compounded in autumn last year when Cokin went into administration. I heard that Lee Filters took over some of their business, but didn't yet have the production capacity to fullfill back orders very quickly  - also the other major maker of 10 stop filters is HiTech & they were caught on the hop by the Cokin thing as well.   
I needed a 10 stop for an advertising job i had coming up in October last year & very luckily I was going via London to it & was able to grab one from Teamwork, but even they only had 1 left after the one I got & no-one else in London had any coming until Jan/Feb 2012. 
I probably don't need to tell you how far behind London, Zurich usually is on the supply chain      
Secondly, on the shops that were shut on Saturdays: which were they - the pro ones?  
ProFot, Graphic Art & Lite & Byte are all profesional suppliers & kit rental outfits & as such they only run Mon - Fri business hours. They are 1st & formost a business to business supplier - It's a bit like you needing a a bit of metal cut for a DIY project & being suprised that the Metalwork factory is closed on a Saturday.   
Hope that explains a bit

i do not usually complain about people, i always give the benefit of the doubt but the latest events really drove me mad!   
just to cut the story short, I have been looking for a handyman for more than a month. I have used the search function here on the forum, read the feedbacks and contacted the most recommended handymen.   
Some did not bother to reply to my PM, others took more than a week to answer (but it's not a problem, i understand people is busy and have limited access to mail), few are charging more than 100 chf just to come to my house (still no issues here, it's the market baby...)   
However at the end I managed to get  , who has nice feedbacks here. 
He came once to my place, attached a light to the ceiling although it did not work properly, a buzz was coming out of it. 
"it's the switch, i'll change it when I come back" he said, "cool" i replied "check your agenda and book your time for me". So the day after I sent him an email asking for another appointment, which he could book only for 2 weeks later.   
So i decided to wait these 2 weeks although i had all the stuff laying around the house and could not invite people over for dinner as the light did not work, but I assumed he could come and do a good job. 
So the big day is coming, I am expecting him at 11 am...then 11:15...11:30 and still no signs of him. So i txt him to ask what the story is and he replied "sorry i have your appointment down for 3pm, however I am sick and I cannot leave the house until i get better"... OK, I understand he was sick but he could still let me know he was not coming, at the end I was waiting for him for the last 2 weeks.   
2 days later and still no news from him, so I did send him another txt "i hope you are well, please let me know when you can come over". This was last Saturday, today is almost THursday and no reply whatsoever.   
So Richard the brit handyman just let me down like that! I was pissed!    
So i had to look for another handyman with short notice and everyone was booked for the next 2 weeks... Fortunately I have managed to get this   over and he did a brilliant job!  
and guess what? the light that Richard installed is defective, there is nothing wrong with the switch. I have to return it although more than 1 month from the purchase is gone. I could have done it on time if Richard spotted it and if he didnt make me wait 2 weeks for nothing.    
BTW this is another lesson learned, never trust 100% positive feedbacks as some people can really prove them wrong.   
end of the rant.

Short answer: it's a cultural thing, pure and simple.  Knocking on your neighbor's door to ask him to turn it down is seen as   of a potential escalation, if you don't know him well, than leaving a note in his mailbox or calling the landlord/police.     
Seems upside down to most English speakers but it's just how it is.   Going through official channels (whether that means the landlord, the police or a letter in the mailbox) is simply  good manners, anything more direct smacks of aggression and vigilantism.  According to the Swiss way of thinking, this is what landlords and police are put on this earth for - so that the rules can be upheld and fairly applied without the need for personal confrontation.     
If you're already on friendly (and I mean friendly, not just amicable) terms with the neighbor, it's a different story. In that case the informality of   making an official complaint is appreciated.  You still don't go downstairs and knock on his door immediately though, that would be an intrusion on his privacy.  Instead, the Done Thing is to ignore the disturbance if at all possible and then mention it to him the next time you see him.  "Last Tuesday evening between 10:30 and 11:15 PM you seemed to be watching TV at a loud volume. Do you think you could turn it down in future as the house rules state that these are supposed to be quiet hours?"  (Note that you still have to refer to the rules! This is important, you want to avoid any whiff of "because I said so".)   
Again, this is really difficult to grasp because it's still completely backwards for us... local custom is what it is though, and the sooner you can get to grips with it, the less mad these encounters will drive you.   
If it's any comfort, once you're friends with your neighbor you can explain it to him over coffee some day and watch him try to bend mind round the difference.

Fortunately, I suspect it's not too common. I once left my wallet in a shop quite a way from where I live here. The shop assistant had looked through the wallet and contacted my bank, the medical insurance company and even my gym, trying to track down an address. The gym and bank had already called me and left messages by the time I got home. There was quite a lot of cash in the wallet but of course it was all intact when I got it back, and the shop assistant refused a reward. I later wrote to her boss to thank her, and learned that she had been given an extra day's holiday as a reward! We all ended up happy, unlike all the participants in the poor OP's tale. There, everyone ended miserable and annoyed. There is a moral in there somewhere!

The other thing is if your family sends you a package and it has a declared value of 100 dollars/francs and is marked Gift, it should be exempt from any charges. Most of what has gone before is correct.    
Maybe there is a misunderstanding, the tenant is required to pay the rental until the next resignation date. If the original tenant finds someone willing and able to take over the contract & to pay the rental, he is still responsible for the payments! If the new tenant defaults and does not pay the rent during the notice period, the original tenant is still liable!    
So maybe this is what the landlord meant. It doesn't really matter if you find someone, you are still responsible for the rent being paid until the contract is correctly finished.    
To get around this problem, the old tenant must make a sub-let contract with the new tenant until the original contract finishes.

I can't speak for the rest of the insurances, but my health coverage through SWICA and my accident insurance through.... through... well, I can't remember who... have been pretty solid.   
Accident insurance is a no brainer. Sprained an ankle pretty badly while doing sport, and simply walked into Permanence at the HB, got the necessaries, and never saw the bill. All directly sent to my insurance.   
Health insurance I always have to pay first and get reimbursed, but it's never been a problem. In fact, I often get more reimbursed than I'm expecting - I simply send all the receipts in an envelope with my policy number to their office in Luzern and I'm done. A couple of days later the money's in my account. I have a pretty high bridge (2500, I think) but some of things such as the share they pay towards my contact lenses or fitness membership get reimbursed without regard to the bridge.   
You have to remember that in Switzerland a couple of thousand is not a lot of money. In the US and probably UK, where debt is king, it's hard to come up with that kind of scratch - but for a Swiss person, it's not at all unreasonable to have the money set by for this kind of thing. If it's difficult for you, then when your next round of insurance negotiation comes up, you should make a point of asking how to pay large bills. Most of the companies I've worked with are pretty reasonable and can come up with some kind of solution.

Yes ... and no. I'm from London and the buzz (night life, bars, restaurants, cafes, shops, just walking around) is very obviously missing from here. But that's to be expected as the population of London is greater than that of Switzerland.   
However, and this is a personal thing, I like meeting new and interesting people. Admittedly not all expats fit into that category but a lot do. I've got friends in Basel from this forum, from couchsurfing.org (they tend to be a bit wacky!), the Association of Chinese Students and Scholars in Basel (don't ask), Facebook and the University. A very diverse bunch of people, most of whom have travelled and worked in many countries.   
In London I sometimes find my "old" friends a bit boring, especially once I'm back there after a few months of living abroad. Here, I can meet people who, for random examples, own a chain of restaurants in Belgium, are studying neuroscience, are musicians, teachers, IT consultants, a Japanese guy who'd spent 3 years cycling around the world, a chef etc etc.   
Now, all the above must exist in London but when the population of a city is 8 million people tend to clump together. In other words, I don't meet such a diverse bunch of people all in one group/place when living in London.

Secondly as far as this appealing to the teen (or even pre-teen) market is concerned then all they're doing is preaching to the converted given my experience at Zürich HB and especially Baden station bus stop. Pretty much all the teen schoolkids are at it. The biggest marketing influence in the teen market is peer pressure. It always has been and always will. A pretty packet isn't going to get anybody started - which is really the crux of ths discussion.   
Should any non smoker suddenly get the urge to buy a packet because of a pretty design you can be assured that the victim upon smoking their first cigarette will blow chunks big time and, in the absence of external pressure, will never touch a cigarette again. It's only through peer pressure (and in my case pure stupid bloody determination) that you get hooked.   
Not to mention that the current pictures on cigarette packets should prevent any sensible non smoker from even trying. The fact of the matter is that tobacco industry markets to the smoker, encouraging them to switch brands. In this day and age marketing to the non smoker, whatever age, simply doesn't work.   
If cigarettes were to be sold in plain white packets it wouldn't matter to a smoker. The only thing that would happen is that possibly the smoker wouldn't switch brands so often. As far as the peer pressure goes I doubt it would make any difference whatsoever.

This is true, no one has a God given right to work anywhere.  Governments first responsibility is to their citizens.   
That being said with my experience, although I got a work visa, I think that Switzerland might improve the system to make industry specific quotas.   
Some industries in Switzerland likely are at risk of "labor dumping" from abroad, which is what the quotas are set up to prevent, this is understandable.  That being said, blanket quotas on the entire job market makes it harder to get works in industries, like mine - IT-, where there is a shortage on only in Switzerland but the Germany, UK, etc.   It is not a benefit to the Swiss economy to make it hard for companies to hire IT people.   
This all goes to politics far more than economics.  It is just politically incorrect to be seen as a pro-foreign labor politician when the job market is not good and their is a general anti-immigrant wave going through Europe.   
I'm from the States, but I think we have a similar system to Switzerland and I don't care for that either.  I prefer Canada and Australia's system, a point system based on qualifications.  Just get that out of the way up front.       
From what I read, U.S. business is against the Canadian model, because they just want the right to choose anyone they want, not pick from a pre-established pool...I would get 75 points on that model, the cut off is 65, and I'm not "super star" or anything. LOL   
not sure how Swiss business would feel, but I know how the SVP would feel. As  a recruiter told me a few months ago when I was looking for work, "Do you have any idea how MANY Indians I could get good paying jobs in Switzerland if not for this damned quota nonsense..."  That's the SVP's nightmare.

Not really a rant, more of an annoyance that I've developed about big brother and it wanting to collect information.   
So I am leaving Switzerland in a few months and recently gave up my flat. I am  now living in a flat share for 3-4 weeks. After that I need to find  another flat share for another few weeks before I finally leave. Because  of this I thought I'd use my old address for any correspondence. I have  arranged with the post office that they collect my mail for me--I  simply just turn up when I feel like it and they get my mail. I am even  ensuring that I do not move out of the city/even postcode so I am above  board with taxes etc.   
However on leaving my old flat my agency required me to give them a new  address so they could inform the kreisbüro. I also have to inform the  kreisbüro with 14 days (which I did today). As I don't have a contract  in my name I now have to get a form signed by the contract owner of the  flat share where I am to show that I haven't just used anyone's address I  guess.   
Fine but makes me think. I am not happy about this big brother actually.  I am above board but still... registration with the authorities is how  it's always been in many countries on continental Europe but the UK and  other anglo saxon countries don't have it. I can now understand why people  didn't want the ID cards in the UK--because it came with a big database  with a £2000 fine for not keeping it up to date. Having said that the UK  does have a serious CCTV camera problem.   
Just think about this next time you get a text message from Stadt  Zuerich detailing to the nearest 1 how many citizens live in the city. Scary stuff.
And a bit of extra info for people reporting this sort of thing: I tried first at the Gemeindepolizei, only to be told (in very friendly terms) that it belonged with the Cantonal police.

1 April 2011  Last updated at  09:34 GMT           
Security firm Websense has been tracking the attack since it started on 29  
March. The initial count of compromised sites was 28,000 sites but this has grown to encompass many times this number as the attack has rolled on.   
Websense dubbed it the Lizamoon attack because that was the name of the first domain to which victims were re-directed. The fake software is called the Windows Stability Center.   
The re-directions were carried out by what is known as an SQL injection  
attack. This succeeded because many servers keeping websites running do not filter the text being sent to them by web applications.        
The fake security software warns about non- existent viruses on victims' PCs    
By formatting the text correctly it is possible to conceal instructions in it  
that are then injected into the databases these servers are running. In this case the injection meant a particular domain appeared as a re-direction link on webpages served up to visitors.   
Early reports suggested that the attackers were hitting sites using Microsoft SQL Server 2003 and 2005 and it is thought that weaknesses in associated web application software are proving vulnerable.   
Ongoing analysis of the attack reveals that the attackers managed to inject code to display links to 21 separate domains. The exact numbers of sites hit by the attack is hard to judge but a Google search for the attackers' domains shows more than three million weblinks are displaying them.

send them registered letter, written in german (since you are in the german part). If you write the letter in english, it is not legally binding in Switzerland and they can always claim they did not understand what you wrote them. They have x number of days to respond (10 days comes to mind, but not 100% sure on this). If they do not respond within this period, you can take further action (legal, complaint, etc). Save the receipt. You may need it later.    
If they do not respond to the registered letter, they are clearly ignoring you and you have to persue it further yourself.    
If you do not have legal insurance, get it. It can be useful for other things. It costs between chf 250-300 per year.    
sales != service, in CH. Customer is not the King, in CH. The furniture is bought and paid for. You found the problem a day after. What is to stop them from saying you did not cause the damage after it was delivered and signed off?    
I am not saying that you did, but that may be one way they are looking at it.    
Often stores outsource delivery and installation to a 3rd party and perhaps there is a mix-up or the store is getting a different story from the delivery people.    
I would suggest (again) you send them a registered letter, and also discuss the problem with someone local (someone who has been here a while and gone through the ropes quite a bit) and get their opinion too.    
Hopefully you have not been "Switzerland'ed".    
Good luck.

For me it's not about how early or late lunch is, but about avoiding it all together. For the vast majority of my working life in England lunch was simply not an option. My work required me to be in places at times where people were not actually working. That meant lunchtimes and evenings were where I could get things done. Simple I hear you say, just take lunch earlier or later. Well it didn't really work like that because the "normal working times" were where I had to do the "hand holding" part of my work.   
To cut a long story short I gave up with lunch when I finally realised how much money I was wasting on sandwiches with just one bite out of them before the phone rang again and I was off to another "emergency". As a result my body got into a rhythm which I've found difficult to break. I really do not feel hungry until around 8pm of a day. If I actually do force lunch down me, then I end up so tired I might as well not bother going back into work for the afternoon.   
My Swiss colleagues think I'm weird. I think I'm weird, and probably you lot do as well.

It saddens me to read this. I have sent out items to forum members, I think some were newbies, and I sent some items without payment in advance, and I have always been paid. Status means nothing to me. I trusted people to pay. Why shouldn't I? I think some of the recipients were surprised that I would take the risk of sending something without payment. Are you forgetting that you have a paper trail, a name and address? Transactions between members are private dealings and unfortunately there is nothing a moderator can do. I think you can name and shame here as long as you publish all the PMs (leaving out the name and address) and prove that there was a transaction. I would do it. In the real world, what you can do, is send a registered letter with a copy of the post office receipt and the correspondence regarding the transaction. Give them 7 days to pay up or else you will take further measures. It will cost you but you will get that back plus what they owe you. The debtor will have this on their credit history and that is going to make their life a misery.    
I have bought and sold items here and I have not had one bad experience. I have met some of the nicest people.

- let's look at some aspects :   
*  legislation :  The revised legislation no longer making it necessary for pedestrians to show their intention to cross the road in reality is a disadvantage for elderly and for handicapped people as well as children 
*  "the Swiss ignore pedestrian crossings" ?  No, not really. Not even those who caused the accidents mentioned. 
*  Fashion:   unfortunately, winter clothes against all logic tend to be dark. I just have to look at me in the mirror from the back. I wear a black leather jacket and have dark hair, which means that the upper half of me in bad weather is invisible for the cardrivers. It so is fairly important that my jeans are not too dark and that my shoes are at least partially in light colours be that white or yellow or orange.  
* putting the foot onto the gas pedal ....  ?   I think that this claim simply is rubbish. 
*  bad planning and not very intelligent signalling of zebra-crossings ?  yes, very often these zebra-crossings may be very useful for the pedestrians, but a car-driver may after the second one think to be through them and reduce attention. There are signs for those zebra-crossings anyway. Why not add to those signs the number of those coming within 100 meters like  "3x" "4x".  There would not be more signals. And then there might be additional things to be done like fluorescent markings being placed on upright things standing right in front of the zebra-crossings.  Many accidents happen in bad light in the dusk of the evening and often at bus-stations with many things obscuring the sight of the drivers 
* sight contact*  ?   To me still very important. As pedestrian you profit from getting into sight contact with approaching drivers. Waving them making it clear what you intend, and thanking them for allowing you through (even if they never really did do so ! ) will help you in every way. And very much the same applies to drivers. I a year ago was on board a car driven by a nephew of some 20 years. It was very warm, and so I put down the window on my side, and supported him with very clear hand signs. We spoke about all moves and the pedestrians well understood what we were doing !   ........................  What I have seen, for many decades, in the Mediterranean and in the USA is that there, the handsigns in actual practice play a far greater role than in inhibited "north-of-the-Alps-Europe"

I was in a store (SATURN) last weekend where there was a Swisscom TV  demo set up. I already have Swisscom TV, but I noticed they were showing  a channel that I didn't have (ESPN America), so I asked the guy and he  said they have a new HD channel package for 9 CHF per month for 9  channels and this was one of them. He then showed me how I can  immediately subscribe by pushing some menu buttons.   
Exctied by this, I ran home, sat on my couch and followed the menu  sequence, only to become dissapointed when this new HD package wasn't in  the list of options    Since it was new, I thought maybe it just somehow wasn't in my menu  yet, or maybe it wasn't available in my area, or whatever. So I called  Swisscom, they said it was available, but that my connection speed was  16Mbps and that a 20Mbps connection speed minimum was required. I said,  oh ok, it's probably the wires in my building, and just forget it since  I'm moving out of this apartment soon anyway, no big deal. Then the Swisscom guy started to insist they send someone to my  apartment to troubleshoot (huh?  ). Since he said it was free, and seemed pretty adimant, so I agreed.    
The following day the Swisscom technician shows up and is there for 2  hours (!!). He replaced the modem, then the socket, then the phone  wouldn't work anymore, then an hour later he finally got the phone to  work again   After all was said and done, he said he couldn't find the problem, but that it was probably the wiring in the building (doh!  ). I said we are moving soon, and he said then it didn't make sense to replace the wiring in the building (gee, ya think?  ).      I have no hard proof, since I didn't see him touch them (he was there 2  hours, I didn't watch him every second), but I do know they were  working before he came, and not after he left    
So what is my "Complaint"? Well, on the one hand, I like Swisscom and  I'm glad they have a customer service team that is ready to go at the  drop of a hat....but on the other hand, why do they insist on wasting my  and their time when it's not needed and unecessary? ...and breaking my  xmas lights, well, i'm still baffled by that one. The lights were kind  of old anyway, but still... Hmm, maybe I should request another Swisscom  tech to come out and repair them?

Oh I do so agree with you, asking if CHF 10'000 is enough to live on makes my blood boil!    
There is no national minimum wage here. The unions have negotiated minimum salaries for certain sectors.    
The minimum payment for a single person on Social Security is about CHF 1'750 tax free (including: Rent, food, health insurance, transport, entertainment). In Bern a family of 3 (Single parent plus 2 older school children) is calculated to need a minimum of CHF 5'600 to live on (including: Rent, food, health insurance, clothing, transport, entertainment). Many jobs in Switzerland pay less than this, e.g. supermarket worker, elevator mechanic, so now you might begin to understand how well off you are.    
To read that the ex- boss of UBS, Marcel Ospel, moved from Basel to Wollerau to save 3.5 million on the tax bill of his CHF 26 million salary   makes me want to bring out the guillotine again.

Hang in there OP. I doubt this is about your nationality but its because you are a foreigner.    
We went through more apartment applications than I can remember when we first got here. I cant remember the number of applications we've made because I've simply blocked it out of my mind. Post traumatic stress syndrome, me thinks.    
But I remember that it was not just foreigners but Swiss people  (yes I had a chat with some of them) that were going for apartment viewings and bringing along documents as well. Letter from the Germinde showing that they are debt free, references from previous landlords etc. I've likened finding a house here to applying for a job. You just have to find a way to stand out amongst the sea of applications.    
I was totally frustrated and even thought of throwing in the towel loads of times (oh the number of times I've given my poor husband grief) as I remember spending almost 2 months every day looking at websites for new apartments as well as visiting them. On the other hand, my husband's colleagues who are Asians like us, and also new to the country, took only 2-3 applications before they found housing outside Zurich. It might be the high demand for housing here and not your nationality. Sure I had people stare at me on trams like I've just stepped out of a spaceship but I usually smile and they either smile back or look away embarassed. It doesnt bother me because I have more important fish to fry.   
Its easy to fall into the "Is-it-because-I-am-xx-thats-why-i-am-treated-this-way" mindset  being in a new country, but I find that going into that  will only make you miserable and resentful of your surroundings and that chip might prevent you from truly making a life that might otherwise turn out to be wonderful.    
Good luck and I really hope you find an apartment soon.

Perhaps the answer given was a bit rude (mostly because I think the guy didn't have manners, but most likely he didn't do it on purpose) but I don't find this to be that strange if understood properly. First of all, a shop owner has the right to decide what kind of customers does he want to address their products to. In this case they might not want to have english-speaking customers because their staff might not be ready to deal in English or because it would be too complicated to prepare everything in English.   
On the other side I'm worried by reading some of the replies given to this thread: email bombings, coupons given in front of the shops, other forms of boycotting etc..   
If I have a shop and decide to not deal with English-speaking customers it's my right to do so and to decide to which public should my products be offered to. It is not discrimination if I don't want to adapt to a foreign language. It might also not be convenient for them to do the effort to translate a product offering in English if the customer base does not justify the effort put in the first place.   
Perhaps the deli manager was a bit rude, but the cultural arrogance shown in this (like in many others) thread I find it to be much worse.

After over 20 years working with both, I'd say it's a matter of approach rather than outcome!   
- On US lead projects it all action first, then it falls over, followed by some thinking followed by another crash, followed by a lot of thinking leading eventually to getting 'something' in production   
- On European lead projects there is endless thinking, followed by something which falls over followed by a bit more thinking leading eventually to getting 'something' in production   
In both cases it's followed by 12 or 18 months of hot fixes, rewriting (sorry I should say refactoring) eventually leading to something fairly stable    
The longer I'm in this industry the more impressed I am at finding an application that actually does what it is supposed to do and has been up and running for a few years with a major crash    
Good luck with that,

There is a reason behind the Ups rule.. in the passed they left expensive parcels such as computers with the neighbor.. ( happened on my shift)    
Long story short , Person A living beside person B ,they fell out some months ago as he damaged his borrowed lawnmower, and now refuses to pay for it.   
Mister A orders a Pc online, worth 2000 chf, but is not home to receive it. 
Ups driver thinks ahead and says " i don't want to be here again with this heavy parcel tomorrow, ill drop it off with the neighbors "   
Mister B happily accepts the computer but "forgets" to inform Mister A ,whom he fell out with .   
Mister A rings Ups, gives out, gets the proof of delivery and notices the name of B on the paper..   Ups done their job, its delivered and signed for.   
This was brought to court, Ups had to pay a sum as settlement, the pc was returned to the correct owner after court came in between.   
The parcel needs to be delivered to the address and signed for by a member that lives there. ( for private deliveries only, not companies), this is why a delivery guy can ask you for proof ( bill or something in your name at the address ) to prove that you actually live there.   
I actually, last week , couldn't sign for a parcel on my girlfriends name  because well..i was not her  ,Moobs or not, i couldn't fool the guy , she had to go and collect it.    
So just to be sure the goods don't come in to wrong hands, they can not deliver next door, as to many issues cropped up doing that before.

I'm thinking that attempting to compare a "normal" airline with an "economy" one is not altogether correct.   
The economy ones seem to have a lot less invested costs within their own business, that's exactly why they can "pass along the savings" to their customers.   
Meanwhile, the normal airlines still have quite a few "additional" bills they need to pay for the (standard) services ("additional" to what is provided by economy class airlines) which they have to pay for as if provided on flights no matter of the actual flight status.    
While I certainly understand the desire (and in many cases actual need) for the refund asap as unexpected expenses were incurred for customers, for a normal airline to come up with a direct refund probably takes some internal financial maneuvering on their part.   
I know, I know... a lot of folks think "well, that's their problem, not mine" but I beg to differ. IF you do not allow for normal businesses to take care of business in ways  , the only choice left will be the economy class businesses.... and   where will we all be.

Unfortunately (or fortunately, depending upon one's p.o.v), the seriousness which may be taken of a post may at times be influenced by the timing of said post.   
For example... a post at 10am on a Wednesday with a complaint about noise may be taken more seriously than a post at 10pm Friday night. After all, there may be spirits involved (both the alcohol type and the "excited about weekend" type) on a Friday evening which would perhaps be absent on a Wednesday.   
Sorry your post was not met with the seriousness which you desired.     
To the topic of post though: 
As others have said, for private citizens, outside of specific days, in some places (Basel for example), it is required to obtain permission for the use of fireworks. 
The reason the shops sell them ahead is to help ensure that there isn't a huge "impossible to deal with" rush on the dates of intended use.   
Meanwhile, if folks - regardless of age - are making unreasonable noise past 10pm, simply call the police. Even the police though will likely take the complaint more seriously on a Wednesday than a Friday.

We were told have half the payment before delivery and half after -  they wanted 25% to secure the date and we assumed 25% on moving day. But, on moving day they wanted 50%....in otherwords, they wanted 75% of the payment by moving day. Very misleading.   
We were very clear we had a budget for shipping and we agreed to a set volume of goods. The packers arrived and they said we had more room budgeted so we added things - some time later got invoice for volume beyond the agreed amount.    
After we arrived in Zurich, we were notified that the goods had not left storage in NJ because we owed them money - really? Yes, they lost our check!!  We had to stop payment and figure out how to wire money - not easy once you leave the country.   
Before they had our things we were told the shipment would arrive by Mid-April. What they appear to have meant is that it will arrive in the UK by then (really, the UK? No body mentioned, but whatever).   
While our goods were in the UK we were told to deal with their subcontractor (EuroUSA)... a group we didn't hire but that was now in charge.   
EuroUSA (the subcontractor) invoiced us for "handling" the goods in the UK. We also were told we got selected for a security inspection and that we had to pay them for it.    
The subcontractor's (EuroUSA) bank didn't exist according to our bank so we were forced to wire to the original company and pay the difference in currency and fees.   
AFTER our goods arrived in the UK, we were told we needed to provide (by snail mail only) our lease agreement and other documents that should have been requested earlier to prevent delays.   
EuroUSA is attempting to invoice a premium because they reserve the right to charge for deliveries over two floors - our apartment is modern and has a large elevator. The difference is a matter of 3 seconds between floors.   
No body at either company is accountable and they have all the leverage since they have our goods. We are now looking, with luck, at delivery in early to mid June... Not Mid April.  If we'd known about Omega/EuroUSA we would have not used them. At this point we wish we'd not shipped anything but just started over once here.

Think UM and AbFab have both hit close to home in that   
a) It is a very popular system for all kinds of companies to advertise their businesses - everything from charities, telecoms companies, utility suppliers, they all use "direct marketing" or "the human advert" to promote their offers and try to beat the competition. Figures (of dubious accuracy I freely admit) show that about 10% of people are at least "open" to the concept (referred to as "positive logical people") but in reality less than 10% of people actually do buy/donate via this method.   
b) The person you were speaking to earns a commission, not based on how much you donate but on how many "contracts" they get completed per day. Probably something like 40-50 CHF per form goes to the "salesperson". (Although that is not normally directly from your donation)   
I used to work in the same job, for nPower in the UK, and I know how soul destroying it can be to be the guy with the clipboard, ignored by many, abused by about half, told by a few how you are the devil incarnate and should be ashamed, and then on very rare occasions someone actually stops and has the human decency to listen to what you have to say.   
So generally I at least stop and listen to anyone, and if they explain it well, and the "deal" they are offering makes sense, and the company is one that I can associate with in some way, then yes I also usually sign up to these things myself. Currently I donate to Save The Children, Greenpeace, Pro Juventute and Pro Infirmis an an annual basis, I think it's 120 CHF to each company debited direct from my account.   
If I'm honest, then for the sake of 40 CHF per month, I really don't feel that pinch, and the regular cash flow to these charities / organisations helps them to budget financially year on year - certainly any amount however small as a regular payment is of much more use to them than a one off cash donation (sorry to sound harsh, but that is the reality of it)

Hi, I can sympathise, having just noticed a chunk missing from my favouriate pashmina.  However, I have just found the following advice that you may find helpful:   
- Ensure all your woollens are washed before storing. This is to  ensure any eggs have been removed and odd as it may seem, it appears  moths are attracted to human scents. 
 - Wipe out all containers or drawers to be used for storage to remove  any existing moth eggs. 
 - Ensure clothes are thoroughly dry before storing 
 - Store clothing in well sealed containers 
 - Try one of the following in a cheesecloth bag; but ensure the bag  doesn't touch the clothes: Bay leaves, cedar shavings, cinnamon sticks,  cloves, eucalyptus leaves, lavender, peppercorns, rosemary, wormwood. 
 Cedar balls and blocks are also said to be effective in repelling  moths, but need to be sanded occasionally in order to "refresh" them.  Cedar kept popping up when researching this topic and many people  reported it to be highly effective. Some people even go as far as lining  their cupboards with cedar panelling.   
Good luck and I am joining you in the battle!

which shows how much is imported. Beans for example usually come from Egypt nowadays. And you have to realize that the situation is more or less like that throughout the year. Much of those imports were not yet availabe as late as the 50ies and the early 60ies, or blocked by customs barriers, and so simply not around. So much improved than in the 60ies and early 70ies, and I do not believe there are too many people who wished to go back. And I also remember the "refrigerator" we had, sized 50x50x40cms, the fresh milk was brought round in the very early morning (the order written the evening before into your "milk-booklet") by the milkman and had to be consumed the same day as it otherwise became undrinkable, and of course the home of grandma WITHOUT fridge with "cool" things kept down in the cellar. Also this not things I would wish to go back to.  Most foodstuff btw. comes in either by truck (Italy, France, Spain, Greece) or by airfreight. There is a big import hall at ZRH airport specially for that business, and a big parking lot right in front of it, always full of trucks from Monday to Saturday. Fruit for example is picked in the very early morning in the Southern Mediterranean, flown over here during the day, and in the shops the following day !     
Sure, there are bad things. Traffic problems can mean tons of fruit and vegetables lost. For instance heavy snowfall in the Ticino can mean that up to 100 trucks are blocked for more than a day, which can result in some 500 to 1000 metric tons of cargo either to be sold at 50% discount in a hurry or even totally lost. This aspect is one of the reason why Zurich Airport is kept open even in times of heavy snowfall.         
**************************************************  *************     
Add to this that meat mostly comes abroad, beef to a wide extent from Poland and lamb from New Zealand, fish products mainly from the Seafood-Market in Paris

It definitely makes a difference when the server's standard of living is heavily dependent on tips.    
And fake or not (lets just admit we don't go to a restaurant looking to marry the serving staff) I would far rather hear "Hi my name's Brittney I'll be your server today" than "Und?"   
I've quoted before Scottish comedian Billy Connolly on these matters. When quizzed by folk back in Scotland as to how he can standard the "fakery" around the Californian "have a nice day" he says he'd far rather hear someone say that and not mean it than someone say "%^&^ off" and mean it. I agree.   
Also smiles are infectious and can actually make you feel better. I once asked a Russian why they look so serious and was told it was because in Soviet times to smile was the preserve of the mentally ill (which I can imagine). Still doesn't explain all the overtly serious suits on the Bahnhofstrasse though or the train station ticket seller who pulls a face like they are in the middle of conducting brain surgery or the waiter who is so above it all. I've never seen so many people who look like their loved one just passed away as I have in Switzerland.

There are other places to live in Switzerland besides Geneva and Zurich. If big city life is the goal maybe it's not the best place.    
I like a compromise- here it's a 13 minute train ride to Geneva 4 times per hour, and I can escape when the exhaust fumes there get to me; it's also a 10 minute walk to the local farm where I can get fresh milk out of a machine and cut my own flowers. I think that's quite a high quality of life!

I use the ignore function in all ways possible. There's too much content on this forum, a lot of which is not so useful, so I use the ignore function to help improve the signal to noise ratio by a small degree. I ignore people who make a lot of posts but never contribute anything intelligent or are always just complaining, I ignore threads that I am tired of seeing on the list of new posts which I never plan to read, and I ignore whole subsections of the forum that I'm not interested in - General Off-Topic, Inernational Politics, Jobs Wanted, and Pet Corner. I'm never going to be interested in those things, so it is better if a computer filters them out for me rather than me having to read all of the thread titles in the list of "New Posts."   
Finding the controls to ignore specific users and threads is easy, but if you want to ignore a forum subsection then you must go to My Settings, Edit Options, Miscellaneous Options, and select them from the list. Strangely, the list of subforums is out of date and doesn't entirely match the current structure of the forum. However, it does appear to work for the subforums that do still exist (I pointed this out a couple of months ago, but nothing appears to have been done about it yet).

I've given to Doctors without borders since I was 17- I got married to my husband and was surprised when he said he would not give money to charities (any charity).    
A little bit of digging later, and I found out that growing up in India, he's seen corruption involving charity money first hand. So his experience tells him you can never be sure money goes to where you want it to go.   
Our compromise is that I continue making a personal donation to Doctors without Borders on a monthly basis without his input, and he sends his parents in India money once a year, that is used to sponsor a monthly feed at the local orphanage. They supervise the whole thing, from the buying of the ingredients to serving the kids. He thinks this is a more 'certain' way of helping. Its not what I would choose, but over 1000 kids get a square meal that day that they'd probably not otherwise receive.   
People have their own particular way of dealing with these matters. When we're passionate about a cause, its somewhat natural to want to proselytize. But its not necessarily the nicest thing.

I'm afraid i'll have to disagree with most people.   
While it is understandable that larger cities have to avoid getting flooded by cars, the P+R solution is nice but only if you have a monthly pay. Even so, there are *no* alternatives like parking outside the city and taking a bus / train. We have a car and we need to park it, be it overnight or for one or two days if we take a train somewhere.   
I still prefer to use my own car to drive when visiting some new place and pay for the parking as it is still cheaper than paying for the train and the eventual bus tickets.   
That said, I still fail to understand how this (lack of parking for longer stays for non residents) is perceived as a major advantage. Maybe if some of the replies brought more logical explanation instead of cynicism then i'd be able to understand this point of view.   
In fact, i'd go as far as to say it is a bit hypocritical to say people should use public transportations if we don't offer them a place to leave their cars which is convenient for the car owner and also the community in general.   
Obviously I didn't mean turning swiss landscape into a parking lot, there are several clever and practical solutions which include underground parking, a few places for non residents with a longer than 12h limit even if they aren't in the center...

I don't feel that my experience is the right one, nor do I feel that anyone's "bad" experience is less valid than my own "good" experiences, but I think it's perfectly acceptable to post good experiences along with the bad, mainly because people tend to complain far more often than they praise. No one gives a shit about people's good experiences, just the bad ones, and this leads people to believe that having shitty neighbors is the norm.
